column1: Ian is OOO today but will be back in tomorrow I believe.
In 11.6  AIC we no longer use IIS. We handle the cert binding through powershell.

Here is the command you can run in and Administrator Powershell window on the app server. You will want to take not of the proper Port that you use in the AIC url. Generally ours are 81 or 481, however some customers use more custom ports such as 443 or others.

column2: Clear out the current certificate from the port using the following PowerShell command:
NOTE: This command assumes that you are using the port 481 for your Access Information Center. Alter the value if you use a different port in your environment.
Copy the new certificate thumbprint. Put the value into the following PowerShell script to bind it to the port:
NOTE: Use the following PowerShell command to list the new certificate:
Add the value to the $certHash variable below.

column1: #build command and pipe to the netsh command
http add sslcert ipport=$($ip):$port certhash=$certHash appid={$guid}"" | netsh

column2: The output message should confirm the successful application of the certificate. Your AIC port is now ready for use with HTTPS.

column1: If you don't want to attempt this yourself or want any kind of further assistance I have assigned some time for you and Ian with the link below for you to schedule
Thank you for taking the time to meet today.
Fixed the AIC link so that it is using port 481 and https.
We also noticed that the AIC is sending errors trying to access the SQL server and logins were failing.

We unlocked the default admin account and reconfigured the SQL credentials, but the error remains. After restarting the service we found that the service is not binding to the port properly and I suspect that the issue is tied to some delay in response from the SQL server.
As discussed please restart the server after hours and we can see if this helps the issue at all.
If not we will try and upgrade the AIC and see if we can get communication with the back end database working correctly.
Subject: Access issue - Access Analyzer 11.6 [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0OL6r1:ref ]

Ian is OOO today but will be back in tomorrow I believe.
In 11.6  AIC we no longer use IIS. We handle the cert binding through powershell.

Here is the command you can run in and Administrator Powershell window on the app server. You will want to take not of the proper Port that you use in the AIC url. Generally ours are 81 or 481, however some customers use more custom ports such as 443 or others.
1.  Clear out the current certificate from the port using the following PowerShell command:
NOTE: This command assumes that you are using the port 481 for your Access Information Center. Alter the value if you use a different port in your environment.
1.  Copy the new certificate thumbprint. Put the value into the following PowerShell script to bind it to the port:
NOTE: Use the following PowerShell command to list the new certificate:
Add the value to the $certHash variable below.
#build command and pipe to the netsh command
http add sslcert ipport=$($ip):$port certhash=$certHash appid={$guid}"" | netsh
The output message should confirm the successful application of the certificate. Your AIC port is now ready for use with HTTPS.
If you don't want to attempt this yourself or want any kind of further assistance I have assigned some time for you and Ian with the link below for you to schedule

[https://nwxcorp.my.salesforce.com/servlet/servlet.ImageServer?oid=00D7000000091pB&esid=018Qk00000LaCUr&from=ext]","RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #442831 - ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000OL6r1:ref - Access issue  - Access Analyzer 11.6    [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0OL6r1:ref ]","william.dammeier@navistar.com","Dammeier, William","techsupport@netwrix.com; holly.smith@international.com","eric.szymanski@netwrix.com","","true","2025-04-25T14:46:28.000Z","true"

The fact that you can now login is much better than it was previously. I suspect the error is related to the SQL timeout errors we were seeing in the logs that indicated that was also stopping the server from binding the ports. I think we should still try and upgrade as there still seems to be some sort of communication issue, but the fact that data is displaying shows that the SQL connection isn't bad, but the startup tasks seem to be the issue as no response to those tasks comes back form the SQL server which leads to the startup delay and the error you are seeing.

Below is a link you can use for to schedule the upgrade, since the AIC doesn't really store much data I think we should try to backup some files and do a full reinstall to the new version to see if we can clear up the startup problem.
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #442831 - ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000OL6r1:ref - Access issue - Access Analyzer 11.6 [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0OL6r1:ref ]

After logging in it does look like there’s data there from the last scan so I’m not sure what if anything is missing or if there actually is an issue or not. Not sure if you can provide any clarification.

The fact that you can now login is much better than it was previously. I suspect the error is related to the SQL timeout errors we were seeing in the logs that indicated that was also stopping the server from binding the ports. I think we should still try and upgrade as there still seems to be some sort of communication issue, but the fact that data is displaying shows that the SQL connection isn't bad, but the startup tasks seem to be the issue as no response to those tasks comes back form the SQL server which leads to the startup delay and the error you are seeing.

Subject: RE: Access issue - Access Analyzer 11.6 [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0OL6r1:ref ]
Thank you for taking the time to meet today.
Fixed the AIC link so that it is using port 481 and https.
We also noticed that the AIC is sending errors trying to access the SQL server and logins were failing.

We unlocked the default admin account and reconfigured the SQL credentials, but the error remains. After restarting the service we found that the service is not binding to the port properly and I suspect that the issue is tied to some delay in response from the SQL server.
As discussed please restart the server after hours and we can see if this helps the issue at all.
If not we will try and upgrade the AIC and see if we can get communication with the back end database working correctly.
Subject: Access issue - Access Analyzer 11.6 [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0OL6r1:ref ]
Ian is OOO today but will be back in tomorrow I believe.
In 11.6  AIC we no longer use IIS. We handle the cert binding through powershell.

Here is the command you can run in and Administrator Powershell window on the app server. You will want to take not of the proper Port that you use in the AIC url. Generally ours are 81 or 481, however some customers use more custom ports such as 443 or others.

column2: Clear out the current certificate from the port using the following PowerShell command:

column1: NOTE: This command assumes that you are using the port 481 for your Access Information Center. Alter the value if you use a different port in your environment.

column2: Copy the new certificate thumbprint. Put the value into the following PowerShell script to bind it to the port:

column1: NOTE: Use the following PowerShell command to list the new certificate:
Add the value to the $certHash variable below.
#build command and pipe to the netsh command
http add sslcert ipport=$($ip):$port certhash=$certHash appid={$guid}"" | netsh
The output message should confirm the successful application of the certificate. Your AIC port is now ready for use with HTTPS.
If you don't want to attempt this yourself or want any kind of further assistance I have assigned some time for you and Ian with the link below for you to schedule
